speaker: CHORUS
content: Two noble families in Verona, equal in status, are reigniting an old feud, causing citizens to kill each other and stain their hands with fellow citizens' blood. From these enemy families, a pair of lovers doomed by fate are born and will kill themselves; their tragic downfall ends their parents' conflict. The dangerous course of their doomed love and their parents' lasting anger, which only the lovers' deaths could end, is the two-hour play we present. If you listen patiently, our performance will fill in any gaps in this summary.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson declares they will not endure insults, using the idiom 'carry coals' to mean tolerate humiliation.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory puns that if they carried coals they would be colliers (coal-carriers), a dirty and lowly job.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson says if they become angry (in choler), they will draw their swords.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory puns on 'draw' as pulling one's neck out of a hangman's collar, mocking Sampson's bravery.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson boasts that he strikes swiftly when provoked.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory retorts that Sampson is slow to become provoked in the first place.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson claims a Montague dog (servant) would provoke him.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory twists 'move' to mean flee, saying true courage means standing firm, so if moved you run away.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson redefines being moved by a Montague dog as a reason to stand and fight, not flee. He adds he will take the wall (privileged side of the sidewalk) from any Montague.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory says taking the wall shows weakness, since the weakest are forced to the wall.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson twists this, saying women as weaker vessels are thrust against the wall, so he will push Montague men from the wall and thrust Montague maids to it, implying sexual assault.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory reminds him the quarrel is between their masters and the servants, not the maids.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson insists he will be a tyrant: civil to maids after fighting the men, then cut off their heads.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory asks for clarification: 'The heads of the maids?'

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson makes a pun on 'maidenheads' (virginity), leaving the meaning ambiguous and crude.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory replies that those who feel it will understand the sense (meaning) of his words, continuing the sexual innuendo.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson boasts that his enemies will feel his strength while he can stand, and he is known to be a sturdy man. This establishes his aggressive, swaggering character.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory puns that if Sampson were fish, he would be poor John, a cheap dried fish, mocking his companion. He then tells Sampson to draw his sword because Montagues approach.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson announces his sword is drawn and promises to support Gregory in a fight.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory deliberately misunderstands 'back thee' as turning one's back to run, teasing Sampson's courage.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson reassures Gregory not to be afraid of him.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory replies, 'No, indeed; I fear you!'—another sarcastic jab at Sampson.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson suggests they keep the law on their side by letting the Montagues start the quarrel.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory says he will scowl as he passes, letting the Montagues respond as they please.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson escalates by saying he will bite his thumb at them, a rude insult that would disgrace them if they tolerate it.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram directly challenges Sampson, asking if he is insulting them.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson admits he is biting his thumb but avoids saying it is at Abram.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram repeats his question more insistently.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson checks with Gregory if the law is on their side if he admits it.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory simply says 'No.'

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson backtracks, saying he bites his thumb but not specifically at Abram, trying to avoid legal blame.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory pointedly asks Abram if he wants to fight, pushing the confrontation further.

speaker: ABRAM
content: He denies wanting to quarrel, using 'sir' as a formal but tense address.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He says if Abram does want to fight, he is ready, and boasts that his master is as good as Abram's.

speaker: ABRAM
content: He dismissively replies that Sampson's master is no better than his own.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He says 'Well, sir' as a noncommittal response, perhaps stalling.

speaker: GREGORY
content: He urges Sampson to say 'better' because Benvolio, a kinsman of their master, is approaching.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He now boldly claims his master is better, as Gregory suggested.

speaker: ABRAM
content: He directly accuses Sampson of lying, escalating the conflict.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: He challenges them to draw swords if they are men, and tells Gregory to remember his 'washing blow'—a slang term for a slashing strike.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He calls them fools and orders them to put away their swords, saying they don't understand the consequences of fighting.

speaker: TYBALT
content: He asks if Benvolio is drawn among these cowardly servants ('heartless hinds'), then tells Benvolio to face him and prepare to die.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He says he is only trying to keep the peace and urges Tybalt to put up his sword or help separate the fighters.

speaker: TYBALT
content: He mocks Benvolio for talking of peace with sword drawn, declaring he hates peace as much as hell, all Montagues, and Benvolio, then attacks.

speaker: FIRST CITIZEN
content: He calls for clubs, bills (a type of spear), and partisans (another pole weapon) to beat down the Capulets and Montagues, showing the spreading chaos.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He demands to know what the noise is and calls for his long sword, eager to join the fray.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She mockingly says he needs a crutch, not a sword, pointing out his age and unfitness for combat.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He insists on his sword, claiming Old Montague has arrived and is waving his blade to insult him.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague angrily calls Capulet a villain and demands to be released to fight.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
content: She commands her husband not to move a step to seek out an enemy.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince scolds the feuding families as rebels who stain their swords with neighbors' blood. He orders them to drop their ill-tempered weapons and listen to his judgment, noting three public brawls started by trivial words. He warns that if they fight again, they will be executed, and summons the heads of both houses to hear his further decision.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He asks who reopened this old conflict and if his nephew Benvolio witnessed the start.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio reports that servants from both houses were already fighting when he arrived. He tried to separate them, but Tybalt appeared, swinging his sword harmlessly at the air while taunting him. More people joined the fight on both sides until the Prince stopped it.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
content: She asks where Romeo is and expresses relief he was not in the brawl.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He tells Lady Montague that before sunrise, while walking due to a troubled mind, he saw Romeo near a sycamore grove west of the city. Romeo noticed him and hid in the woods. Benvolio, understanding Romeo wanted solitude as he himself did, respected his wish and avoided him.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague says Romeo has often been seen there at dawn, crying and sighing, but as soon as the sun rises he retreats to his room, shutting out daylight to create an artificial night. He fears this mood is ominous unless good advice can address the cause.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks his uncle if he knows the reason for Romeo's sadness.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He replies that he does not know and cannot get Romeo to tell him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks whether Montague has pressed Romeo for an answer.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague says he and others have tried, but Romeo keeps his feelings secret and unsearchable, like a bud eaten by a worm before it can open. If they could learn the source of his sorrow, they would gladly provide a cure.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Noticing Romeo approaching, he suggests they step aside so he can learn Romeo's problem or be strongly refused.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: He hopes Benvolio will succeed in hearing Romeo's true confession, then he and Lady Montague leave.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He greets Romeo with 'Good morning, cousin.'

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo expresses surprise that it is still so early in the day.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio notes that it has just struck nine o'clock.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo sighs that sad hours feel long, then asks if his father just left quickly.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio confirms it was Romeo's father and asks what sadness makes his hours seem long.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he lacks the thing that, if he had it, would make time seem short.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio guesses he is in love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he is out, meaning out of love's favor.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio clarifies, asking if he is out of love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo explains he is out of the favor of the woman he loves.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio laments that love, which seems gentle, proves harsh and tyrannical in experience.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo complains that blind love still finds ways to get what it wants. He abruptly asks where to dine, then reflects on the recent brawl, saying it involves hate but more love. He then launches into a series of oxymorons describing love's contradictions: brawling love, loving hate, heavy lightness, serious vanity, and more, concluding that he feels a love that brings no joy. He asks if Benvolio is laughing.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says no, cousin, he would rather weep.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks why his good heart weeps.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says he weeps at the oppression of Romeo's good heart.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says that is love's transgression. His own griefs weigh heavily, and Benvolio's sympathy only adds more sorrow. He then describes love as a smoke from sighs, a fire in lovers' eyes when cleared, and a sea fed by tears when troubled. He calls it a discreet madness, a choking bitterness, and a preserving sweetness, then bids farewell.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio tells him to wait, saying he will go along and that Romeo wrongs him by leaving like this.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo dismisses this, saying he has lost himself and is not truly present; Romeo is somewhere else.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks Romeo to tell him seriously who he loves. 'In sadness' here means 'in earnest' or 'seriously'.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo responds sarcastically, asking if he should groan while telling him, playing on the word 'sadness'.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He clarifies that he doesn't want groaning, just a serious answer about who Romeo loves.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo compares being asked to speak seriously about love to asking a sick man to make his will—both are poorly timed. He then admits he loves a woman.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He says he guessed correctly when he assumed Romeo was in love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo calls Benvolio a good marksman and confirms the woman he loves is beautiful.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He jokes that a beautiful target is easiest to hit, using archery as a metaphor for winning love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says Benvolio missed the mark: his beloved cannot be hit by Cupid's arrow because she is chaste like Diana, goddess of chastity. She is armored against love's advances, won't listen to sweet words, withstands admiring looks, and cannot be bribed. She is rich in beauty but poor because her beauty will die with her, leaving no heirs.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He asks if she has sworn to remain chaste.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He confirms she has, and by saving herself she wastes her beauty, since it won't be passed on. She is too beautiful and wise, and by making him despair she denies herself happiness. Her vow not to love makes him feel dead while alive.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He advises Romeo to forget her.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks how he can possibly stop thinking of her.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He suggests Romeo look at other beautiful women.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo argues that seeing others would only make him appreciate her more, like black masks reminding us of the fair faces beneath. A blind man never forgets his lost sight, and any new beauty would only serve as a reminder of her. He concludes Benvolio cannot teach him to forget.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He vows to prove his advice correct or die trying, using a financial metaphor ('pay that doctrine' means 'prove that teaching').

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet says he and Montague are equally bound by the same penalty to keep the peace, and he thinks it should be easy for men as old as them.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris says both Capulet and Montague are of honorable reputation, and it is a pity they have been enemies so long. He then asks again for Capulet's answer to his marriage proposal.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet repeats his earlier answer: his daughter is still young, not yet fourteen, and he wants to wait two more years before considering her ready for marriage.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris argues that girls younger than Juliet have become happy mothers.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet replies that those who marry too young are often ruined. Juliet is his only surviving child and his hope. He encourages Paris to woo her and win her heart, saying his own approval is only part of the matter—if she agrees, he will consent. He invites Paris to a feast that night where he will see many lovely young women, and Juliet, though one among them, may not stand out. He tells a servant to go invite the people on a list.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant complains that he has been given a list of names to find but cannot read it. He humorously mixes up trades and tools (like a shoemaker with a yard, tailor with a last) to show he is out of his element, and says he must find someone educated to help.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio advises Romeo that one strong emotion can displace another—like one fire putting out another, or a new pain lessening an old one. He suggests Romeo find a new love to cure his current heartache.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo responds sarcastically, suggesting a plantain leaf (a folk remedy) is good for a broken shin, mocking Benvolio's advice as simplistic.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks what Romeo means by 'that.'

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says, 'For your broken shin,' continuing his sarcastic deflection.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio exclaims, 'Why, Romeo, are you mad?'

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he is not mad but more confined than a madman—imprisoned, starved, whipped, and tormented (metaphorically by love). He then breaks off to greet the servant.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant returns the greeting and asks if Romeo can read.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo replies yes, he can read his own unfortunate fate in his misery—a pun on 'reading' as interpreting his situation.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant says maybe Romeo learned that by heart, but asks if he can actually read text he sees.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says yes, if he knows the letters and the language.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant politely bids Romeo farewell, using the phrase 'rest you merry' to mean 'stay happy'.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo stops the servant and reads aloud the invitation list, which includes Rosaline, then asks where the party is being held.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant replies 'Up', meaning 'up there' or 'at the location'.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo clarifies whether the gathering is for supper.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant confirms it is at his master's house.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks whose house it is.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant says it is his master's house.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo realizes he should have asked whose house it was earlier.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant reveals his master is Capulet and invites Romeo to 'crush a cup of wine' (drink wine) if he is not a Montague, then bids him farewell again.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio notes that Rosaline will be at the feast and urges Romeo to go and compare her with other beauties using an 'unattainted eye' (unbiased view), promising Romeo will then think his beloved swan is a crow by contrast.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo responds with a religious metaphor: if his eyes are so devoted they see falsely, then let them burn like heretics; he claims the sun has never seen anyone as fair as Rosaline since the world began.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio dismisses this, saying Romeo only saw Rosaline alone, not compared to others; he insists that if Romeo weighs Rosaline against another girl at the feast, even the best will seem inferior.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees to go, but only to enjoy the sight of his own love, not to see anyone better.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She asks the Nurse to call her daughter Juliet to come to her.

speaker: NURSE
content: Swearing by her virginity at age twelve, she says she already told Juliet to come, then affectionately calls for her with pet names like lamb and ladybird, and worries aloud where she is.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks who is calling for her.

speaker: NURSE
content: She tells Juliet it is her mother.

speaker: JULIET
content: She politely presents herself and asks what her mother wants.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She first tells the Nurse to leave so they can speak privately, but then reconsiders and asks her to stay because she remembers the Nurse should hear their discussion, noting that Juliet is at a fitting age for marriage.

speaker: NURSE
content: She claims she knows Juliet’s exact age down to the hour.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She states that Juliet is not yet fourteen.

speaker: NURSE
content: She insists she would bet fourteen of her teeth—though she only has four—that Juliet is not yet fourteen, then asks how long it is until Lammas-tide.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She replies it is a fortnight and a few extra days.

speaker: NURSE
content: She says that on Lammas Eve at night Juliet will be fourteen, then recalls that her own daughter Susan was the same age but is now dead. She vividly remembers weaning Juliet on that day eleven years earlier during an earthquake, applying bitter wormwood to her breast so the baby would reject it, and tells how Juliet became fussy and the dovehouse shook. She adds that Juliet could stand and run by then, and recounts a time Juliet fell and got a bump, after which the Nurse’s husband joked that she would fall backward when older—meaning sexually—and Juliet stopped crying and said yes.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She tells the Nurse to stop talking.

speaker: NURSE
content: She agrees but still laughs at the memory of Juliet stopping crying to say yes, despite having a large bump on her forehead from the fall, and repeats the husband’s jest about falling backward when older.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks the Nurse to stop talking as well.

speaker: NURSE
content: She says she is done, blesses Juliet as the prettiest baby she ever nursed, and wishes to live to see her married.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She says that marriage is exactly what she came to discuss, and asks Juliet how she feels about getting married.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says marriage is an honor she has not even considered dreaming about, showing her youth and lack of interest in the topic.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse exclaims 'An honor!' and jokes that if she were not Juliet's only nurse, she would say Juliet had sucked wisdom from her breast, meaning she is clever beyond her years.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet urges Juliet to think of marriage, noting that in Verona, respected ladies younger than her are already mothers. She recalls she was Juliet's mother at about Juliet's current age, then reveals that the noble Paris wants to be her suitor.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse enthusiastically describes Paris as a man of wax, meaning he is as handsome and perfect as a waxwork model.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet adds that Verona's summer does not have a flower as fine as Paris, using a metaphor for his beauty.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse emphatically agrees, calling Paris a true flower indeed.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet asks if Juliet can love Paris and tells her she will see him at the feast. She uses an extended metaphor of reading a book: Juliet should study Paris's face like a volume, find delight in his beauty, examine his features, and see how they harmonize. What is unclear in this book she can find explained in the margins of his eyes. She calls Paris a precious but unbound book that only needs a cover—a wife—to be complete. Just as a fish belongs in the sea, it is fitting for external beauty to hide inner worth. This book is admired by many, like a golden-clasped volume containing a golden story; by having him, Juliet will share all he possesses without losing anything.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse interrupts to say women do not become less by marrying, but bigger—meaning they gain status and often pregnancy.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet presses Juliet for a quick answer: can she accept Paris's love?

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet cautiously agrees to look at Paris to see if looking inspires liking, but she will not let her gaze penetrate deeper than her mother's permission allows, showing her obedient but reserved attitude.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant announces the guests have arrived, supper is served, Lady Capulet is called for, Juliet is asked for, the Nurse is being cursed in the pantry, and everything is in chaos. He must go to serve and urges them to come immediately.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet says they will follow, then tells Juliet that Paris is waiting.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tells Juliet to go and seek happy nights to go with happy days, a rhyming couplet wishing her joy in love and marriage.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks whether they should offer a formal excuse for arriving at the party, or just enter without any apology.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says elaborate introductions are out of fashion; they will not perform a masked Cupid act or a memorized prologue. He says they will let others judge them as they wish, but they will dance a measure (a dance) and then leave.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks for a torch because he does not want to dance; feeling heavy-hearted, he will carry the light instead.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio insists that Romeo must dance.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he will not dance; while Mercutio has nimble dancing shoes, his own soul is like lead, pinning him to the ground.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio tells Romeo that, as a lover, he should borrow Cupid’s wings and rise above ordinary limits.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he is too deeply wounded by Cupid’s arrow to fly with his light feathers; he is so weighed down that he cannot leap above his sadness and sinks under love’s burden.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio replies that if Romeo sinks under love’s burden, he is burdening love in return, which is too heavy for something so tender.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo questions whether love is tender; he finds it rough, rude, boisterous, and painful like a thorn.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio advises Romeo to fight back if love is rough—prick love back and defeat it. He then asks for a mask to hide his face, saying he does not care if anyone notices his odd looks; let the frowning ladies blush instead.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges everyone to enter and start dancing immediately.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo again asks for a torch; let the carefree ones dance on the rushes (floor covering). He says he will follow an old saying and be a candle-holder, watching others play a game he is finished with.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio uses wordplay: 'dun’s the mouse' means 'keep still,' but if Romeo is stuck (dun) in the mire of love, they will pull him out. He says they are wasting daylight (time) by delaying.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo objects that they are not actually burning daylight.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio clarifies that by delaying they waste their torchlight needlessly, like lighting lamps by day. He says his intended meaning is wiser than mere cleverness.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees their intention in going to the masque is good, but it is not wise to go.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio asks Romeo why he is reluctant to attend the feast, prompting him to explain his mood.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he had a dream last night, hinting at his troubled state of mind.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio replies that he also dreamed, setting up a playful exchange.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks what Mercutio dreamed, continuing their banter.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio puns that dreamers often lie, meaning both tell falsehoods and recline in bed.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo counters that dreams can be true, but only while asleep in bed.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio launches into his Queen Mab speech, describing the tiny fairy who causes people’s dreams by riding over them as they sleep. He details her miniature chariot and how she makes lovers dream of love, courtiers of etiquette, lawyers of fees, ladies of kisses (sometimes punished with blisters), courtiers of favors, parsons of extra income, and soldiers of battle—before they wake frightened. He adds that Mab tangles horses’ manes and maids’ hair, and teaches maids to bear weight, making them women. This extravagant speech mocks Romeo’s belief in dreams.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo interrupts, telling Mercutio to stop because he is talking nonsense.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio agrees that he talks of dreams, which are the products of a lazy mind, made of empty fantasy—as insubstantial as air and more changeable than the wind, which now flatters the cold north but may turn angrily toward the south.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says this talk of wind is distracting them; supper is over and they will be late for the party.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo fears they are too early, because he dreads that some fateful event beginning tonight will end his despised life by an untimely death. But he resigns himself to whatever power guides his course and urges them onward.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio orders the drum to sound, signaling their departure for the Capulet feast.

speaker: FIRST SERVANT
content: He complains that Potpan is not helping clear the tables, sarcastically noting that carrying or scraping a trencher (wooden plate) is too much for him.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: He remarks that when only one or two men do all the work, and they are unwashed, it is a disgusting situation.

speaker: FIRST SERVANT
content: He orders the removal of join-stools (simple stools) and the court-cupboard (sideboard), asks someone to save him a piece of marchpane (marzipan), and to let in Susan Grindstone and Nell, calling for Antony and Potpan.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: He simply replies 'Yes, boy, ready.'

speaker: FIRST SERVANT
content: He tells them they are being asked for in the great chamber.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: He says they cannot be in two places at once, urges everyone to be cheerful and brisk, and uses the proverb 'the longer liver take all' (the survivor gets everything).

speaker: CAPULET
content: He welcomes the guests, teasing that ladies without corns should dance, and those who hesitate (make dainty) must have corns. He nostalgically recalls his own masked dancing days, now gone, and calls for music and dancing. He then orders more light, tables put away, and the fire quenched because the room is hot, expressing pleasure at the unexpected fun.

speaker: CAPULET'S COUSIN
content: He swears by the Virgin Mary (By’r Lady) that it has been thirty years.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He disagrees, saying it was only twenty-five years ago at Lucentio’s wedding, and they wore masks then.

speaker: CAPULET'S COUSIN
content: He insists it was longer, since Lucentio’s son is now thirty.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He refuses to believe it, saying the son was only a ward (minor under guardianship) two years ago.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks who the lady is that the knight is holding hands with.

speaker: SERVANT
content: He replies that he does not know.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He exclaims that her beauty outshines the torches, comparing her to a jewel in an Ethiopian’s ear and a dove among crows. He vows to touch her hand after the dance and renounces his past loves, declaring this his first sight of true beauty. This speech marks his instant infatuation with Juliet.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Recognizing Romeo’s voice as a Montague, he calls for his rapier, accusing Romeo of coming masked (antic face) to mock (fleer) their celebration. He swears by his family’s honor that killing him would be justified. This shows the immediate threat of violence.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He questions why Tybalt is so enraged.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt alerts his uncle Capulet that Romeo, a Montague enemy, has come to their feast out of spite to mock their celebration. This establishes the immediate threat of violence and Tybalt's hot-headed nature.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet asks for confirmation that the intruder is young Romeo, showing he recognizes the name and perhaps knows Romeo's reputation.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt confirms it is indeed Romeo, whom he calls a villain, reinforcing his anger and desire for confrontation.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet tells Tybalt to calm down and leave Romeo alone, noting he behaves like a dignified gentleman and that Verona considers him virtuous. He insists that as host he won't allow any insult to a guest in his house, demanding Tybalt show a pleasant face instead of scowling. This reveals Capulet's authority and unexpected tolerance toward Romeo.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt insists such a villain deserves a hostile reception and declares he will not tolerate Romeo's presence, defying Capulet's order.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Enraged, Capulet asserts his authority, calling Tybalt 'goodman boy' (a belittling term) and insisting Romeo will be tolerated. He accuses Tybalt of trying to start a mutiny and 'set cock-a-hoop' (cause disorder) among the guests. This outburst shows Capulet's temper and determination to keep peace at his feast.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt protests that it is shameful to allow Romeo to remain, still resisting his uncle's command.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet escalates his rebuke, calling Tybalt a saucy (insolent) boy and warning that his defiance may scathe (harm) him. He calls Tybalt a princox (an impertinent youth) and orders him to be quiet, while also calling for more light and cheer to restore the festive mood, showing he's trying to manage both Tybalt and the party.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt says being forced to be patient while filled with anger makes him tremble. He will withdraw now, but predicts this intrusion that seems harmless will turn bitterly poisonous later. This foreshadows future conflict and Tybalt's vengeful plans.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo addresses Juliet with a metaphor comparing her to a holy shrine and himself to a pilgrim. He says if his hand profanes her, his lips are like two blushing pilgrims ready to atone with a gentle kiss. This begins their poetic, religiously-inflected courtship.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet plays along with the metaphor, saying he undervalues his hand, which shows polite devotion. She notes that saints allow pilgrims to touch their hands, and that palm-to-palm contact is the holy kiss of pilgrims (palmers). She cleverly deflects the kiss while continuing the religious wordplay.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks if saints and pilgrims don't also have lips, pushing his argument for a kiss.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet replies that yes, pilgrims and saints have lips—but for prayer, subtly maintaining her resistance while staying within the metaphor.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo pleads that just as hands pray, so should lips; he asks her to grant his prayer (a kiss) so his faith doesn't turn to despair. This cleverly turns religious devotion into romantic pursuit.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says saints do not move, though they grant prayers, giving a coy permission for him to kiss her while she remains still.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says then she should not move while he receives the effect of his prayer, and claims that by kissing her, his sin is purged. This completes their witty exchange and leads to their first kiss.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet playfully suggests that if Romeo has taken a sin from her lips by kissing her, then her own lips must now possess that sin. This continues their flirtatious exchange about their first kiss.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo delights in her witty framing of their kiss as a sin, calling it a sweetly presented offense, and asks her to return his 'sin' by kissing him again.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet remarks that Romeo kisses according to the rules, meaning expertly or conventionally, possibly with a hint of teasing.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse interrupts to say Juliet's mother wants to speak with her, moving the plot and separating the lovers.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks who Juliet's mother is, showing his sudden concern about her family identity.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse explains that her mother is the lady of the house, a good and virtuous woman, and that she herself nursed Juliet. She adds that whoever marries Juliet will have plenty of money ('the chinks').

speaker: ROMEO
content: Horrified, Romeo realizes Juliet is a Capulet, his family's enemy. He exclaims that his life is now owed to his foe, meaning his love binds him to an enemy.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges Romeo to leave because the party is at its peak and it's time to go.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees but says his anxiety only grows, as he now knows Juliet's identity.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet insists the guests stay for a light meal ('banquet'), but when they leave, he thanks them and calls for torches, noting by his faith ('by my fay') that it's getting late and he'll go to bed.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks the Nurse to identify a gentleman across the room, beginning her inquiry about Romeo.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse mistakenly identifies him as the son and heir of old Tiberio (likely a misremembrance or error for another guest).

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks about another man leaving, trying to pinpoint Romeo without naming him.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says that one is probably young Petruchio, again giving a wrong name.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks about the one who followed and wouldn't dance, clearly describing Romeo.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says she doesn't know, leaving Juliet without the answer she seeks and increasing dramatic tension.

speaker: JULIET
content: She tells the Nurse to find out his name, and says that if he is married, her grave will be her wedding bed—meaning she will die unmarried.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse reports that his name is Romeo, a Montague, the only son of their great enemy.

speaker: JULIET
content: She laments that her only love comes from her only hate; she saw him too early without knowing who he was, and now knows too late. This is a monstrous or unnatural birth of love to her, that she must love a hated enemy.

speaker: NURSE
content: She repeats 'What’s this?' in surprise, asking what Juliet is saying.

speaker: JULIET
content: She dismisses her outburst as a rhyme she just learned from someone she danced with, hiding her true feelings.

speaker: NURSE
content: She calls back 'Right away!' to someone offstage, then tells Juliet they should leave because all the guests have gone.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks how he can leave when his heart remains with Juliet. He tells his body to turn back and find its center, meaning his heart, then climbs the wall into the Capulet orchard.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio calls for Romeo, using 'cousin' here to mean kinsman or close friend.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jokes that Romeo has sensibly stolen away home to bed.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio insists Romeo came this way and jumped the orchard wall, urging Mercutio to call for him.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mockingly summons Romeo as if by magic, calling him by lover's traits and invoking Rosaline's features. He references Cupid and the tale of King Cophetua loving a beggar-maid, then declares Romeo must be dead to the world.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio warns that if Romeo hears this mocking, he will be angered.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio claims his conjuring won't anger Romeo, but summoning a spirit in his mistress's magical circle until she dismisses it would be an insult. He insists his own invocation is honest and meant only to call Romeo forth.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio suggests Romeo has hidden among the trees to keep company with the moody night, and that his blind love suits the darkness.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio puns that if love is blind, it cannot hit its target. He then makes a series of crude sexual jokes about medlar fruit, which was slang for female genitalia, and 'poperin pear' for the male, wishing Romeo and his mistress were such fruits. He concludes he is going to his trundle bed, finding the field too cold.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio agrees they should leave, since it is pointless to search for someone who does not wish to be found.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says that only someone who has never been hurt can mock the pain of others. He sees Juliet at her window and compares her to the sun rising in the east, urging her to outshine the pale, envious moon. He tells her not to remain a virgin servant of the moon, whose greenish garb is worn only by fools. He wishes she knew he was there, and though she is silent, her eyes speak. He imagines her eyes are like stars that have swapped places with the real stars, and her cheek is so bright it would outshine them. He longs to be the glove on her hand so he could touch her cheek.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet sighs, expressing sadness or longing.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo urges her to speak again, calling her a bright angel as glorious as a heavenly messenger appears to mortals gazing upward.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet wonders why Romeo must be Romeo, a Montague. She asks him to deny his family name, or swear his love so she can stop being a Capulet.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks himself whether he should keep listening or speak now.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says only his name is her enemy; he would still be himself without it. A name is just a convention—a rose by any other name would smell as sweet, and Romeo without his title would still be perfect. She asks him to give up his name and take her in exchange.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees to her offer: if she calls him her love, he will abandon his name and be newly baptized.

speaker: JULIET
content: Startled, Juliet asks who is hidden in the dark and has overheard her private thoughts.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he doesn’t know how to identify himself because his name is hateful to him since it is an enemy to her; he wishes he could destroy it if it were written.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet recognizes his voice after only a few words and asks if he is Romeo, a Montague.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he is neither if she dislikes either.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks how and why he came, noting the high orchard walls and the danger of death if her relatives find him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says love gave him wings to fly over the walls; stone barriers can’t keep love out, and love dares to do anything, so her kinsmen are no obstacle.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet warns that if her family sees him, they will kill him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo replies that more danger lies in her angry look than in twenty of their swords; if she looks kindly on him, he is protected from their hatred.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says she would not want them to see him there for anything in the world.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says the darkness conceals him from his enemies, and unless she loves him, he would rather they find and kill him than live without her love. 'Prorogued' means postponed, and 'wanting' means lacking. This shows his reckless passion and willingness to die for love.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks how he discovered her location, showing surprise and caution.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He claims love guided him, giving advice while he provided sight. Though not a sailor, he would travel to the farthest shore for her, comparing her to precious 'merchandise.' This uses metaphor to express his devotion.

speaker: JULIET
content: She is glad the night hides her blush, since she has spoken so openly. She would prefer to be formal and deny her words, but abandons etiquette. She worries that if he swears love, he might be lying, as lovers' false oaths were said to amuse Jove. She admits she has been too forward but promises to be truer than those who play hard to get. She asks pardon, saying her passion was revealed unintentionally and should not be seen as shallow. 'Fain' means gladly, 'compliment' means formal manners, 'perjuries' are false oaths, 'light' means promiscuous, and 'discovered' means revealed. This speech reveals her internal conflict between passion and propriety.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He begins to swear his love by the moon, a traditional romantic oath.

speaker: JULIET
content: She interrupts, warning him not to swear by the inconstant moon, lest his love prove equally changeable.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks what he should swear by instead.

speaker: JULIET
content: She tells him not to swear at all, or if he must, to swear by himself, whom she worships like a god. 'Idolatry' means worship of an idol. This elevates him to a divine status in her eyes.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He starts to swear by his heart's love, but she cuts him off.

speaker: JULIET
content: She stops him, saying though she delights in him, their vows feel too hasty and sudden, like lightning that vanishes instantly. She hopes their love will grow like a bud into a flower with time. She bids good night, wishing him as much peace as she feels. 'Unadvis'd' means ill-considered. This shows her practical fear that their rush may endanger their love's future.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks if she will leave him without fulfillment.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks what fulfillment he could possibly have tonight.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He wants the exchange of their faithful vows of love.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says she already gave her love before he asked, yet wishes she could give it again.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks if she would take it back, and for what reason.

speaker: JULIET
content: She explains she only wants to be generous and give it again. Her love is as limitless as the sea; the more she gives, the more she has. Hearing the Nurse call, she hastily says she will return and asks him to be true. 'Frank' means generous, and 'bounty' means generosity. This expresses the infinite, reciprocal nature of her love amid practical interruption.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He fears this perfect night is only a dream, too wonderful to be real. This shows his disbelief at his sudden happiness.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says if his love is honorable and intends marriage, he should send word tomorrow about when and where the ceremony will be; she will then entrust her entire life to him and follow him anywhere. This speech advances the plot by proposing a secret marriage.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse calls from offstage, interrupting the lovers.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says she will come soon, but warns him that if his intentions are not good, he should stop pursuing her and let her grieve.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse calls again, increasing the urgency.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says she is coming right away and tells him to end his effort and leave her to her sorrow, promising to send a message tomorrow.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He swears by his soul’s welfare, an expression of his sincere devotion.

speaker: JULIET
content: She bids him good night a thousand times as she exits.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says it is worse to be without her light. Lovers going to each other are as eager as schoolboys leaving books, but parting from each other is as sad as going to school. This metaphor contrasts the joy of union with the sorrow of separation.

speaker: JULIET
content: She quietly calls him back, wishing for a falconer’s voice to call her 'tassel-gentle' (male falcon, meaning Romeo) back. She says her situation makes her speak softly, or else she would shout his name until Echo’s voice grew hoarse. This shows her longing and the constraints of their secrecy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says his soul is calling his name, and lovers’ voices at night sound sweet and musical.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says his name.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He responds affectionately.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks what time tomorrow she should send someone to him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says by nine o’clock.

speaker: JULIET
content: She promises not to fail and says the wait will feel like twenty years; then she admits she has forgotten why she called him back, showing her distracted, lovesick state.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he will remain there until she recalls her love for him, showing his reluctance to leave.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet playfully replies that she would keep forgetting, just so he would stay, because she loves his presence so much.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo continues the playful exchange, saying he would stay so she keeps forgetting, and he would forget any home but hers.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet notes it is nearly morning and wants him to leave, but only as far as a spoiled child’s pet bird—letting it go a little but pulling it back with a silk thread, jealous of its freedom. 'Wanton' means playful or spoiled; 'gyves' are shackles.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo wishes he were that bird, showing his desire to be close to her even if restrained.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says she wishes the same, but fears she would kill him with too much affection. She bids good night, calling their parting a sweet sorrow, and says she will keep saying good night until morning.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo wishes sleep and peace for her, then says he wishes he were sleep and peace to rest with her. He will go to his confessor Friar Laurence for help and to tell of his good fortune. 'Ghostly Sire' means spiritual father; 'hap' means luck or fortune.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The dawn is replacing night, and I must fill my willow basket with both poisonous and medicinal plants. The earth is both a womb and a tomb, producing many different plants, each with its own virtues. Nothing is so evil that it does not give some good to the earth, and nothing so good that it cannot be abused. Virtue becomes vice if misused, and vice can be dignified by proper use. This flower contains both poison and medicine: smelling it revives, tasting it kills. Similarly, humans have grace and base desire; if the worse prevails, death destroys them.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Good morning, father.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Bless you! Who greets me so sweetly so early? Young man, it suggests a troubled mind to say good morning so early instead of sleeping. Old men have care in their eyes and cannot sleep, but youth with clear minds should sleep soundly. Your early rising tells me you are disturbed, or else you haven't been to bed tonight.

speaker: ROMEO
content: The last part is true; I had a sweeter rest.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: God forgive sin. Were you with Rosaline?

speaker: ROMEO
content: With Rosaline, my spiritual father? No, I have forgotten that name and its sorrow.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: That's my good son. But where have you been then?

speaker: ROMEO
content: I'll tell you before you ask again. I have been feasting with my enemy, where suddenly someone wounded me who is also wounded by me. Our cures lie in your help and holy medicine. I bear no hatred, for my plea also helps my foe.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Be plain, good son, and straightforward in your meaning; a puzzling confession gets only a puzzling absolution.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Then know plainly that my heart's dear love is set on the fair daughter of rich Capulet. She loves me as I love her, and all is settled except what you must join in holy marriage. I'll tell you the details later, but I beg you to consent to marry us today.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Holy Saint Francis! What a change is this! Is Rosaline, whom you loved so dearly, so quickly abandoned? Young men's love lies not in their hearts but in their eyes. Jesus Mary, how much salt water washed your pale cheeks for Rosaline! How much salt water wasted to season a love that had no taste. The sun hasn't yet cleared your sighs from heaven, your old groans still ring in my old ears. Here on your cheek sits the stain of an old tear not yet washed off. If you were ever yourself, these woes were all for Rosaline, and are you changed? Pronounce this verdict then: women may fall when men are weak.

speaker: ROMEO
content: You often scolded me for loving Rosaline.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: For infatuation, not for loving, my pupil.

speaker: ROMEO
content: And you told me to bury love.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Not in a grave to put one love in and take another out.

speaker: ROMEO
content: I pray you, do not scold me; the one I love now returns grace for grace and love for love. The other did not.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says that Juliet knew Romeo’s love was just memorized and recited without true understanding, like someone who can recite words but not actually spell them. Then he calls Romeo a young waverer and tells him to come along, promising to help him in one way: this marriage might turn out so happily that it transforms the hatred between their families into pure love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo urges them to leave immediately, saying he feels a sense of urgent hurry.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar advises moving wisely and slowly, because those who run fast are prone to stumbling. This serves as a warning against Romeo’s impulsiveness.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio wonders where Romeo is and if he came home last night. Tonight here means last night.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says Romeo did not go to his father's house, because he spoke with Romeo's servant.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio blames Rosaline, calling her a pale, hard-hearted woman, for tormenting Romeo so much that he will surely go mad.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio reports that Tybalt, a relative of old Capulet, has sent a letter to Romeo's father's house.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio immediately assumes it is a challenge to a duel.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio believes Romeo will respond to the challenge.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jokes that anyone who can write can answer a letter, playing on the word answer.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio clarifies that Romeo will answer Tybalt himself, accepting the dare.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mocks Romeo as already defeated by love: wounded by Rosaline's glance, pierced by a love song, and struck by Cupid's blunt arrow. He doubts Romeo can fight Tybalt. Butt-shaft means a blunt arrow for practice.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks what kind of fighter Tybalt is.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio describes Tybalt as an expert, formal duelist who follows all the rules precisely, like a musician keeping time. He uses fencing terms like passado and punto reverso, calling him a prince of cats from folklore.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks for clarification about the fencing terms.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio complains about affected, fashionable people who use newfangled speech and manners, calling them flies and fashion-mongers who care more about style than comfort.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio announces Romeo's arrival.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jokes that Romeo looks thin and lovelorn, comparing him to a dried fish. He mockingly says Romeo's new love inspires bad love poetry, dismissing famous beauties like Laura and Cleopatra as unremarkable. He greets Romeo in French, mocking his fashionable loose trousers and his absence the previous night.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo returns the greeting and asks what trick or deception Mercutio means.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He asks if Romeo cannot understand the slip, meaning an escape or evasion, teasing him for sneaking away.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He apologizes, saying his business was important and in such circumstances a man may be excused for being impolite.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He jokes that Romeo’s case forces a man to bow at the knees, implying Romeo was with a woman.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He clarifies that Mercutio means to curtsy, acknowledging the bawdy implication.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He says Romeo has exactly understood his meaning.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He calls Mercutio’s explanation very polite, with ironic praise.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He boasts that he is the very model or perfect example of courtesy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He notes that pink means a flower, playing on the word.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He agrees with Romeo’s point.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He quips that his shoe is well decorated with flowers, punning on pump as a shoe and flowered as ornamented.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He urges Romeo to keep up the jest until his shoe is worn out, so the joke outlasts the shoe and remains uniquely clever.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He mocks the joke as thin and solitary, playing on single-soled (cheap) and solely singular (alone).

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He calls for Benvolio to intervene because his wit is exhausted.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He urges Mercutio to use switches and spurs to speed his wit, or he will claim victory in their contest.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He says if Romeo’s wits lead them on a wild-goose chase, he gives up, for Romeo has more foolishness in one wit than he has in all five senses, asking if he followed the goose joke.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He retorts that Mercutio was never with him in anything unless he was there for the foolishness, turning the insult back.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jokingly threatens to bite Romeo's ear for his witty remark, a playful gesture of mock aggression.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo calls Mercutio a 'good goose' and tells him not to bite, continuing the banter with a food metaphor.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He says Romeo's wit is like a bitter apple or sharp sauce—pungent and biting.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo retorts that such sharp wit is appropriately paired with a sweet goose, turning the insult back on Mercutio.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He praises Romeo's flexible wit, comparing it to cheveril (kid leather) that stretches from narrow to broad.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo twists 'broad' to call Mercutio a 'broad goose'—a foolish woman—extending the pun to insult him.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He approves of Romeo's return to sociable banter instead of lovesick moping, comparing love to a foolish jester hiding his toy.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio interrupts, urging Mercutio to stop his crude story.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio quips that Benvolio wants him to stop 'against the hair'—against his natural grain or desire.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio replies that otherwise Mercutio would have made his story large (long or indecent).

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio claims he was already finished and meant to occupy the argument no longer, denying any intent to prolong it.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo exclaims 'Here’s goodly gear!' and 'A sail, a sail!'—mocking the Nurse's arrival as if spotting a ship.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He adds 'Two, two; a shirt and a smock,' joking that both a man (Peter) and woman (Nurse) have arrived.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse calls for her servant Peter.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter responds 'Anon,' meaning 'right away.'

speaker: NURSE
content: She asks Peter for her fan, showing her fussy demeanor.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He jests that the Nurse should hide her face because her fan is more attractive than her face. This insult mocks her appearance and sets a bawdy tone for their exchange.

speaker: NURSE
content: She greets the gentlemen with a formal 'God give you good morning.'

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He replies with 'God give you good evening,' deliberately using the wrong time of day to mock her.

speaker: NURSE
content: She questions whether it is indeed evening, showing her confusion at his jest.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He insists it is evening because the 'bawdy hand' (sexual pun on clock hand) is on the 'prick' (pun on noon marker and penis) of noon. This crude time-telling continues his sexual mockery.

speaker: NURSE
content: She exclaims 'Shame on you!' and questions what kind of man he is.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says he is a man God made to ruin, self-deprecatingly playing along with Mercutio's humor.

speaker: NURSE
content: She agrees with his remark, repeating 'for himself to mar' with approval, then asks where to find young Romeo. Her malapropism 'quoth a' for 'quoth he' shows her comic character.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says he can tell her, but Romeo will be older when found than when sought, playing with time. He identifies himself as the youngest of that name 'for fault of a worse' - meaning only because there's no worse one.

speaker: NURSE
content: She simply says 'You speak well,' either missing or ignoring his wordplay.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He puns on Romeo's 'for fault of a worse,' asking if 'the worst' is 'well,' then praises the wordplay as 'wisely taken.'

speaker: NURSE
content: She asks to speak privately with Romeo, but misuses 'confidence' for 'conference' (private conversation), another malapropism.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: He jokes that she will 'endite' (malapropism for 'invite') him to supper, playing on her verbal errors.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He shouts 'A bawd, a bawd!' (procuress) and 'So ho!' (hunting cry), implying the Nurse is a prostitute hunting for Romeo.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks what Mercutio has found, playing along with the hunting metaphor.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: He says he found no hare (slang for prostitute) unless it's an old, stale one in a Lenten pie. His song continues the metaphor: an old gray-haired hare is good Lenten food, but one that's moldy ('hoar') before being eaten is too much for twenty people. He then invites Romeo to his father's for dinner.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees to follow his friends, showing his eagerness to leave the scene.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mockingly bids farewell to the Nurse, repeating 'lady' to exaggerate her age and social pretensions.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse asks Romeo who that rude man was, using 'saucy merchant' for an impudent fellow and 'ropery' for roguish tricks.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo dismisses Mercutio as a man who talks a lot but does little, highlighting Mercutio's boastful nature.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse angrily vows to punish anyone who insults her, calling Mercutio a 'scurvy knave' (worthless rascal) and denying she is one of his 'flirt-gills' (loose women) or 'skains-mates' (cutthroat companions), then scolds Peter for not defending her.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter defensively says he saw no one mistreat her and claims he would have drawn his weapon if needed, provided the quarrel was just and legal.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse, still agitated, says she is trembling with anger, then shifts to her mission: she warns Romeo not to lead Juliet into a 'fool's paradise' (false hopes) or deceive her, stressing Juliet's youth and the seriousness of such betrayal.

speaker: NURSE
content: She excitedly interrupts Romeo, saying she will tell Juliet his protestation (declaration), which she interprets as a proper offer from a gentleman.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks what she plans to tell Juliet, noting she isn't listening properly.

speaker: NURSE
content: She repeats that she will tell Juliet about his protest, which she considers gentlemanly.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo instructs the Nurse to have Juliet find a way to go to confession ('shrift') at Friar Lawrence's cell this afternoon, where she will be confessed ('shriv'd') and married, and he offers payment for her trouble.

speaker: NURSE
content: She politely refuses the money.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He insists she take it.

speaker: NURSE
content: She agrees that Juliet will be there this afternoon.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tells the Nurse to wait behind the abbey wall; within an hour his servant will bring a rope ladder ('cords made like a tackled stair') that will serve as his means ('convoy') to reach the height ('topgallant') of his joy at night. He bids her be trustworthy and he will reward her.

speaker: NURSE
content: She blesses him and asks him to listen.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks the Nurse what she has to say, showing his eagerness for news from Juliet.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse asks if Romeo's servant is trustworthy, using a proverb meaning that a secret is safe with two people if one is removed.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo assures her his servant is completely reliable, using 'true as steel' to mean steadfast.

speaker: NURSE
content: She praises Juliet's sweetness and mentions Paris's unwanted advances; Juliet prefers a toad to him. The Nurse teases Juliet by praising Paris, making her turn pale. She then playfully links Romeo and rosemary by their initial letter.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo confirms both words start with 'R', prompting the Nurse's jest about dog sounds.

speaker: NURSE
content: She jokes that 'R' sounds like a dog's growl, then recalls Juliet's clever sayings about Romeo and rosemary, which would please him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo politely asks the Nurse to give his greetings to Juliet.

speaker: NURSE
content: She agrees enthusiastically and calls for her servant Peter, as Romeo exits.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter responds 'Anon,' meaning 'right away' or 'I'm coming.'

speaker: NURSE
content: She urges Peter to go ahead of her and quickly, showing her haste to return to Juliet.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet anxiously waits for the Nurse, who was supposed to return in half an hour. She worries the Nurse might be delayed, then imagines that love’s messengers should be as fast as thoughts, which move ten times quicker than sunlight, or like doves and Cupid that swiftly carry love. She notes three hours have passed since nine o’clock, and if the Nurse were young and passionate, she would move as quickly as a ball in a game. But old people act slow and lifeless like lead.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tells Peter to wait at the gate.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet notices the Nurse looks sad and urges her to deliver any news cheerfully; if the news is good, she should not spoil it with a gloomy expression.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says she is tired and needs a rest, complaining that her bones ache from the trip.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet impatiently says she wishes they could trade places—her bones for the Nurse’s news—and begs her to speak.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse exclaims at Juliet’s impatience, asking if she cannot wait a moment since she is out of breath.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet cleverly points out that if the Nurse has enough breath to say she’s out of breath, her excuse is longer than the actual news would be. She demands simply whether the news is good or bad, promising to wait for details after that.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse teasingly criticizes Juliet’s choice of Romeo, saying she doesn’t know how to pick a man. She praises his looks, legs, hands, feet, and body as beyond compare, and though he may not be the peak of courtesy, she guarantees he is gentle. She then oddly asks if Juliet has eaten at home.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet dismisses this, saying she already knew all that, and urgently asks what Romeo said about their marriage.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse complains again of her aching head and back, blaming Juliet for sending her out and risking her health by running around.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet politely says she is sorry the Nurse is unwell, but persists in asking what her love said.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says Romeo spoke like an honest, courteous, kind, handsome, and virtuous gentleman, then abruptly asks where Juliet’s mother is.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is confused by the odd reply, repeating the Nurse’s own words: ‘Your love says, like an honest gentleman, “Where is your mother?”’

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse exclaims in mild exasperation: ‘Are you so impatient? Indeed, I suppose you are. Is this the remedy for my aching bones? From now on, deliver your own messages.’

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says all this fuss is unnecessary and again asks what Romeo said.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse finally gets to the point, asking if Juliet has permission to go to confession today.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is anxiously waiting for the Nurse to return with news from Romeo.

speaker: NURSE
content: She tells Juliet to hurry to Friar Lawrence’s cell where Romeo is waiting to marry her. The Nurse notes Juliet’s cheeks are blushing at the news. She will go fetch a rope ladder so Romeo can climb to Juliet’s room that night. The Nurse calls herself a drudge doing the hard work for Juliet’s pleasure, but Juliet will soon bear the 'burden' of marriage. She urges Juliet to go to the church while she goes to dinner.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet joyfully exclaims she is hurrying to her great fortune and bids a warm farewell to the trustworthy Nurse.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He prays that heaven will bless this marriage so that later times do not reproach them with sorrow. This sets a solemn tone for the secret wedding.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He agrees but says any future sorrow cannot outweigh the joy he gets from seeing Juliet even briefly; he asks the Friar to marry them, and then even death can do its worst, since having her as his own is enough.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He warns that intense joys end violently, like fire and gunpowder exploding when they meet; even sweet things can become sickening if overindulged, so he advises loving moderately because rushing can be as bad as going too slowly.

speaker: JULIET
content: She greets the Friar respectfully as her spiritual advisor.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says Romeo will thank her on behalf of both of them, acknowledging their shared gratitude.

speaker: JULIET
content: She replies that she owes Romeo just as much thanks, otherwise his thanks would be excessive.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He tells Juliet that if her joy is as great as his and she is better at expressing it, she should use her voice to describe the happiness they both feel in seeing each other.

speaker: JULIET
content: She responds that true feeling is richer in substance than in showy words; those who can count their worth are poor, but her love is so immense she cannot tally half its value.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He urges them to come with him to be married quickly, saying they cannot be left alone until the church has united them as one.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges Mercutio to leave because the hot weather makes people irritable and the Capulets are out, so a fight is likely if they meet.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio compares Benvolio to a man who brags about his sword in a tavern but picks fights over nothing after a drink. 'Claps me' means 'slaps down,' 'drawer' is a bartender.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks if he really seems like such a person.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio insists Benvolio is as quick-tempered as anyone in Italy, easily provoked and quick to anger.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks what he would quarrel about.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio lists absurd reasons Benvolio would fight: over beard hair, nut-cracking (mocking his hazel eyes), coughing, or a tailor’s fashion choices. 'Doublet' is a jacket, 'riband' a ribbon. He concludes Benvolio’s head is as full of quarrels and as addled (confused) as an egg is full of meat (yolk).

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio jokes that if he were as quarrelsome as Mercutio, anyone could buy permanent ownership of his life for a short time—meaning he’d be killed quickly. 'Fee simple' means absolute ownership.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mocks Benvolio’s legal term 'fee simple' as silly, then Tybalt enters.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio warns that the Capulets are approaching.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio dismisses the danger, saying he doesn’t care.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt tells his companions to stay near, then greets the others with 'good-den' (good evening) and asks to speak with one of them.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio挑衅地回应，说如果只跟一个人说一句话，那就再加点别的，比如一句话加一拳。

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt says he’s ready to fight if given a reason.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio sarcastically asks if Tybalt can’t find a reason without being given one.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt says Mercutio associates with Romeo, using 'consortest' which can mean 'keep company with.'

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio pretends to take 'consort' as meaning a group of musicians, threatens discord, and brandishes his sword ('fiddlestick'), saying it will make Tybalt dance. 'Zounds' is a mild oath.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges them to move to a private place to discuss their grievances calmly or to leave, since they are in a public space where everyone is watching. This sets the scene for the coming conflict and shows his role as a peacemaker.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio defiantly says that eyes are meant to look, so let them stare; he refuses to move for anyone's convenience. His stubbornness highlights his hot-headed nature and disregard for public opinion.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt sarcastically wishes peace upon Mercutio and then notes that Romeo, the person he is looking for, has arrived.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mocks Tybalt, saying he would be hanged if Romeo wears Tybalt's livery (uniform), meaning Romeo is not his servant. He sarcastically suggests Tybalt go to a dueling field and Romeo will follow as his 'man' in that sense. This insults Tybalt's pride and challenges his claim over Romeo.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt tells Romeo that the only term his love for him allows is 'villain,' a deep insult questioning Romeo's honor. This directly provokes a duel.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo responds that he has reasons to love Tybalt which excuse the anger such a greeting would normally provoke; he says he is no villain and bids farewell, implying Tybalt does not truly know him. This reflects Romeo's secret marriage to Juliet making Tybalt his kinsman.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt dismisses Romeo's words as no excuse for the offenses he believes Romeo has committed, and commands him to turn and draw his sword.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo insists he never harmed Tybalt and loves him more than Tybalt can understand until he knows the reason; he says he values the Capulet name as dearly as his own and urges Tybalt to be satisfied. This further hints at his secret marriage without revealing it.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio exclaims in disgust at Romeo's calm, dishonorable submission. He draws his sword, saying 'Alla stoccata' (a fencing thrust) wins the day, and calls Tybalt a rat-catcher (mocking his name) and challenges him to fight.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt asks what Mercutio wants with him, playing along with the confrontation.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio, calling Tybalt 'Good King of Cats' (mocking 'Tybalt' from a cat in folklore), says he wants one of his nine lives, which he will boldly take, and depending on how Tybalt treats him later, he will dry-beat (beat without drawing blood) the other eight. He dares Tybalt to draw his sword quickly or he will strike him before it is out.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt draws his sword and says he is ready for Mercutio, accepting the challenge.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo urges Mercutio to put his sword away, trying to prevent the fight.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio ignores Romeo and challenges Tybalt with 'your passado' (a forward fencing thrust), and they begin fighting.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo calls on Benvolio to help beat down their swords, shame the gentlemen for this outrage, and reminds them the Prince has forbidden fighting in Verona's streets. He cries for them to stop as Tybalt and his followers exit.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio reveals he is wounded, curses both the Montague and Capulet houses with a plague, says he is done for ('sped'), and asks if Tybalt got away unharmed. This marks the turning point where Mercutio's death escalates the tragedy.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks if Mercutio is injured.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio downplays his wound as a scratch but says it is enough to be serious; he calls for his page to fetch a surgeon. 'Marry' is a mild oath.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tries to reassure Mercutio that the injury cannot be too bad.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jests grimly that his wound is not very deep or wide, but enough to kill him; 'grave' puns on serious and burial place. He says he is done for ('peppered') and curses both the Montague and Capulet houses. He blames Romeo for coming between them in the fight. 'Zounds' is an oath; 'by the book of arithmetic' mocks Tybalt's precise, formal dueling style.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo explains that he intervened with good intentions.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio asks Benvolio to help him inside before he faints, repeats his curse on both houses, and says they have turned him into food for worms (i.e., killed him).

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo reflects that Mercutio, a close friend and relative of the Prince, was mortally wounded for his sake, and his own reputation has been damaged by Tybalt’s insult. He laments that his love for Juliet has made him soft and less courageous.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio announces that Mercutio is dead and that his noble spirit has risen to the sky too soon.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo declares that this day’s tragic fate will affect more days to come; this is only the start of sorrows that others will finish.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio warns that Tybalt is returning angrily.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo, seeing Tybalt return after killing Mercutio, renounces gentle mercy and calls for furious rage to guide him. He demands Tybalt take back the insult 'villain,' saying Mercutio’s soul is waiting for Tybalt’s to join it, so one or both of them must die.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt calls Romeo a wretched boy who kept company with Mercutio and says he will join him in death.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says their fight will decide that outcome.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio urges Romeo to flee because the citizens are alerted and Tybalt is dead; he warns that the Prince will sentence him to death if caught.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo exclaims that he is the plaything of bad luck.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks why Romeo is still lingering.

speaker: FIRST CITIZEN
content: The First Citizen asks which way Tybalt, the murderer of Mercutio, ran. This shows the immediate chaos and pursuit after the fight.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio simply states that Tybalt lies dead here, pointing out the body.

speaker: FIRST CITIZEN
content: The citizen orders someone to come with him in the Prince’s name, asserting authority to arrest the offender.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince demands to know who started the fight, seeking the instigators of the brawl.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio tells the Prince he can explain the whole unfortunate event: Tybalt lies slain by Romeo, who killed Mercutio.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet mourns Tybalt as her cousin and nephew, then demands the Prince, as a just ruler, require a Montague’s death in return for Tybalt’s blood.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince asks Benvolio to name who began the bloody fight.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio recounts the events: Romeo tried to calm Tybalt, but Tybalt, ignoring peace, fought Mercutio. Romeo intervened, but Tybalt under Romeo’s arm fatally stabbed Mercutio, then fled and later returned to fight Romeo, who killed Tybalt and fled. Benvolio swears this is true.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet claims Benvolio is biased as a Montague relative and lies; she says many Montagues fought but only one died, and demands Romeo’s execution for killing Tybalt.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince notes Romeo killed Tybalt, and Tybalt killed Mercutio, then asks who owes the price for Mercutio’s death.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague argues Romeo was Mercutio’s friend and his action only carried out what the law would have done—executed Tybalt.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince exiles Romeo immediately, saying he too has suffered from their feud (Mercutio was his kinsman), fines both families heavily, and warns that mercy to killers only leads to more murder.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet implores the sun's horses to hurry toward sunset so night can come, allowing Romeo to visit her secretly.
