She imagines lovers can see by their own beauty or love's blindness fits night. She asks night to teach her to lose her virginity modestly and hide her blushing cheeks until love grows bold. She calls Romeo her day within night, whiter than snow on a raven, and fantasizes that after death he will become stars making night so beautiful the world ignores the sun. She feels she has bought love's mansion but not possessed it, and this day is as tedious as a child waiting to wear new robes. She sees the Nurse coming with news, and any word of Romeo is heavenly.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse confirms she has the ropes Romeo asked for, throwing them down in distress.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks why the Nurse is wringing her hands and what news she brings.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse exclaims repeatedly that Romeo is dead and they are ruined, using old-fashioned expressions of grief like 'well-a-day' and 'alack the day'.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks if heaven could be so envious as to cause this.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says Romeo can do this, though heaven cannot, and expresses shock that anyone would have thought it of him.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet calls the Nurse a devil tormenting her, saying this torture belongs in hell. She asks if Romeo killed himself, saying a mere 'Ay' would poison her more than a cockatrice's deadly gaze. She says she would not be herself if he were dead, and that brief sounds will decide her happiness or misery.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says she saw the wound on his breast—God save the mark—and describes him as a pitiful corpse, pale as ashes and covered in blood, making her swoon at the sight.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet tells her heart to break at once, calls herself a bankrupt, and tells her eyes to go to prison and never see freedom again. She tells her body to return to earth and end life, so she and Romeo can share one funeral bier.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse mourns Tybalt as her best friend, a courteous and honest gentleman, and laments having lived to see him dead.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks what storm blows so contrary—is Romeo slaughtered and Tybalt dead? She calls Tybalt her dearest cousin and Romeo her dearer husband, then says the final trumpet of Judgment Day should sound, for who is left alive if those two are gone?

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse clarifies that Tybalt is gone and Romeo, who killed him, is banished.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks in horror if Romeo's hand shed Tybalt's blood.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse confirms it did, alas the day.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet erupts in oxymorons, calling Romeo a serpent heart hidden by a flowering face, a dragon in a fair cave, a beautiful tyrant, angelic fiend, raven with dove feathers, wolf-like lamb. She says he is the opposite of what he seems—a damned saint, honorable villain. She asks why nature placed a fiend's spirit in such sweet flesh, like a book with vile matter beautifully bound, and that deceit lives in a gorgeous palace.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says there is no trust, faith, or honesty in men; all are perjured, forsworn, worthless, and dissemblers. She calls for her man and some aqua vitae (alcohol) because these griefs make her old, and she wishes shame upon Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet curses the Nurse’s tongue for wishing shame on Romeo, saying shame itself would be ashamed to touch his brow, which is a throne for honor. She then regrets having criticized him earlier.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse asks if Juliet will praise the man who killed her cousin Tybalt.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet defends Romeo as her husband and laments that she, his wife of only three hours, has spoken ill of him. She reasons that Tybalt would have killed Romeo, so Romeo’s survival is a comfort, yet she weeps because Romeo’s banishment is worse than Tybalt’s death—it feels like endless, boundless sorrow, as if all her family and love are dead.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says Juliet’s parents are weeping over Tybalt’s body and offers to take Juliet to them.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says her parents can weep for Tybalt, but her tears will be for Romeo’s banishment. She addresses the bed cords, saying they were meant to lead Romeo to her bed, but now she will die a virgin widow, with death taking her maidenhead instead of Romeo.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tells Juliet to go to her room and says she knows where Romeo is hiding—at Friar Lawrence’s cell—and will bring him to comfort her tonight.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks the Nurse to give Romeo a ring and tell him to come for a final farewell.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He calls Romeo out, saying misfortune loves his qualities and he is married to disaster. This introduces Romeo’s tragic state and the Friar’s role as counselor.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He anxiously asks what the Prince’s judgment is and what new sorrow awaits him. This shows his dread and anticipation of punishment.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says Romeo is too acquainted with misery, then reveals he brings news of the Prince’s doom. This delays the answer to build tension.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks if the judgment is anything less than doomsday, showing his fear that it will be execution.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says a gentler sentence came from the Prince: not death but banishment. This is the crucial revelation of Romeo’s fate.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He reacts with horror, saying banishment is worse than death and begs for death instead. This reveals his despair at being separated from Juliet.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He confirms the banishment and urges patience, saying the world is wide. This attempts to console but ignores Romeo’s emotional attachment to Verona.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says there is no world outside Verona, only torture and hell; banishment is exile from the world, which is death misnamed. He accuses the Friar of killing him with a golden axe—a seemingly kind but fatal blow. This speech uses extreme metaphor to express his despair.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He scolds Romeo for ingratitude, noting the law demanded death, but the merciful Prince changed it to banishment. He insists Romeo fails to see this mercy. This highlights the theme of rash youth versus reasoned mercy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He argues that heaven is where Juliet lives; even animals and unworthy things can see her, but he cannot. Flies can touch her hand and steal kisses from her blushing lips, but he is banished. He asks if the Friar has no quicker means of death than banishment, and says only the damned in hell use that word. He accuses the Friar, as a holy man and friend, of mangling him with that word. This long, emotional speech uses vivid contrasts and hyperbole to show his torment.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He calls Romeo a foolish madman and asks to be heard. This shows his attempt to regain control of the conversation.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He interrupts, fearing the Friar will speak again of banishment. This shows his fixation and refusal to be comforted.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says he will give him armor against that word—the sweet milk of adversity, meaning philosophy—to comfort him in exile. This introduces the Stoic consolation he offers.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He rejects philosophy unless it can create a Juliet, move a town, or reverse the doom; otherwise it is useless. This dismisses abstract comfort in favor of his concrete, passionate grief.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He remarks that madmen have no ears, meaning Romeo won’t listen to reason. This underscores the communication gap between them.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He retorts that how can madmen have ears when wise men have no eyes, implying the Friar is blind to his suffering. This witty comeback shows Romeo’s despair-fueled cleverness.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar asks to discuss Romeo's situation calmly.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says the Friar cannot understand his pain because he hasn't experienced it himself. He lists his woes: youth, new marriage, Tybalt's murder, his own banishment, and despair so deep he measures his own grave.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar hears knocking and urgently tells Romeo to hide.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo refuses to move unless his groans hide him like a mist. This shows his extreme self-pity and refusal to face reality.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar grows more frantic with repeated knocking, telling Romeo to run to the study while he answers the door, exasperated by Romeo's foolishness.

speaker: NURSE
content: From offstage, the Nurse asks to enter and says she comes from Juliet.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar welcomes her and invites her in.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse anxiously asks where Romeo is.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He points out Romeo on the floor, overwhelmed by his own tears.

speaker: NURSE
content: She says he is in the same state as Juliet—both weeping uncontrollably. She urges him to be a man and stand up, asking why he falls into such deep despair (a deep 'O' meaning a groan or lament).

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo simply says 'Nurse,' acknowledging her.

speaker: NURSE
content: She responds fatalistically that death comes to everyone.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks if she spoke of Juliet and whether Juliet now sees him as a murderer for killing Tybalt, who was nearly her own blood. He wonders where she is, how she is, and what his secret wife says about their ruined love.

speaker: NURSE
content: She says Juliet says nothing but weeps, alternating between collapsing on her bed and crying out for Tybalt and Romeo.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo imagines his name, like a bullet from a gun, has killed Juliet as it killed Tybalt. He asks the Friar which part of his body his name resides in so he can destroy it.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar scolds Romeo for his suicidal impulse, saying his tears are womanish and his rage beastly. He lists Romeo's blessings: Juliet lives, he killed Tybalt in self-defense, the sentence is exile not death. He urges Romeo to go comfort Juliet, then flee to Mantua before the watch is set, promising they will later reveal the marriage and seek pardon.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says she could have stayed all night listening to the Friar's wise advice, admiring his knowledge, and promises to tell Juliet that Romeo will come.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tells the Nurse to do so and to have his beloved get ready to scold him, referring to Juliet's expected anger over Tybalt's death.

speaker: NURSE
content: She gives Romeo a ring from Juliet, urging him to hurry because it is getting late.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo feels his spirits lifted by receiving the ring, which renews his hope and comfort.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar tells Romeo to leave immediately, either before the night watch is posted or at dawn in disguise, stay in Mantua, and his servant will send news of any good fortune here. He shakes his hand and says goodbye, emphasizing the lateness.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says that only an overwhelming joy calls him away, otherwise parting so quickly would be painful, and he bids farewell.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet explains that unfortunate events have prevented him from discussing Paris's proposal with Juliet. He notes that she and he both loved Tybalt dearly, and he fatalistically adds that everyone is born to die. He says it is too late for Juliet to come down tonight, and he would have gone to bed an hour ago if not for Paris's visit.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris remarks that this time of grief is not suitable for courtship. He bids Lady Capulet good night and asks her to give his regards to Juliet.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet says she will convey Paris's message to Juliet tomorrow morning, but tonight Juliet is shut away with her sorrow. 'Mew'd up' means confined or enclosed, emphasizing her isolation.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet tells Paris he will make a bold offer of Juliet's love, confident she will obey him in all matters. He instructs his wife to visit Juliet before bed and inform her of Paris's love, and to tell her she will marry him next Wednesday—then he pauses to ask what day it is.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris answers that it is Monday.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet decides Wednesday is too soon and changes the wedding to Thursday. He asks Paris if he approves of the haste and says they will have only a small celebration with a few friends, since holding a large feast so soon after Tybalt's death might make them seem indifferent to his loss. He confirms Thursday as the date.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris eagerly says he wishes Thursday were tomorrow, showing his enthusiasm for the marriage.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet finalizes Thursday as the wedding day and tells his wife to prepare Juliet. He bids Paris farewell and calls for a light to his chamber, joking that it is so late it will soon be early. 'Afore me' is a mild oath meaning 'upon my soul.'

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet insists it is still night, claiming the bird they heard was a nightingale (which sings at night) rather than a lark (which sings at dawn), trying to persuade Romeo to stay longer. She mentions the nightingale sings on a pomegranate tree nearby.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo corrects her, saying it was the lark, a morning bird, and points to the streaks of light in the eastern sky. He poetically describes night ending and day arriving, then states his dilemma: he must leave to survive or stay and be executed.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet denies that the light is dawn, suggesting it is a meteor exhaled by the sun to light his way, and urges him to stay since he doesn't need to go yet.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says he is willing to be captured and die if Juliet wishes it. He denies the signs of morning, calling the light merely a reflection of the moon (Cynthia) and claims the bird is not the lark. He declares he would rather stay and face death than leave.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet now admits it is day and urgently tells Romeo to flee. She complains the lark's song is harsh and divisive, unlike its usual sweet music, and references a myth that larks and toads exchanged eyes. She wishes they had exchanged voices too, since the lark's song is like a hunt's-up (a morning hunting song) driving him away.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo laments that as the light increases, their sorrows grow darker.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse calls for Juliet's attention.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet responds to the Nurse.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse warns that Juliet's mother is coming and that day has arrived, advising her to be careful.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet speaks metaphorically to the window, saying that letting in the day means letting out life (Romeo's departure feels like a loss of life).

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo bids farewell and says he will climb down after one kiss.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet, distressed, calls Romeo by many loving names and says she will need to hear from him constantly, feeling that time will drag unbearably until they meet again.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo promises he will not miss any chance to send her messages.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet anxiously asks if they will ever see each other again.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo expresses confidence they will meet again and says their current sorrows will become stories for future conversation.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says she has a foreboding soul and imagines Romeo, as he descends, looking like a dead man at the bottom of a tomb, unsure if her vision is failing or if he truly appears pale.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tells Juliet that she looks sorrowful in his eyes too. He says grief drains their vitality like drinking blood, then bids farewell. This marks their painful morning separation after their wedding night.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet addresses Fortune, the goddess of fate, calling her changeable. She questions why Fortune would deal with Romeo, who is faithful, and asks her to be fickle so she will return him quickly. This shows her anxiety about his exile.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet calls from offstage to see if Juliet is awake, establishing her sudden intrusion into the scene.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet wonders why her mother is calling, noting it is unusual for her to be up so late or early. She asks what reason brings her here, showing surprise and wariness.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet enters and asks Juliet what is wrong, using a common phrase of the time meaning 'what’s the matter?'.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says she is not well, giving a vague excuse to hide her real distress over Romeo’s departure.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She assumes Juliet is still crying over Tybalt’s death. She sarcastically asks if Juliet will wash him from his grave with tears, then says even if she could, she couldn’t bring him back. She advises stopping: some grief shows love, but too much shows lack of wisdom.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet insists she must weep for such a deeply felt loss, using wordplay on 'feeling' to mean both emotional and physical pain.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She replies that Juliet will feel the pain of the loss, but not the friend she weeps for, meaning Tybalt is gone forever.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says because she feels the loss so strongly, she cannot help but always weep for the friend.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She claims Juliet weeps not for Tybalt’s death but because the villain who killed him still lives.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet plays ignorant and asks which villain she means.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She identifies the villain as Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says there is a great distance between 'villain' and Romeo. She asks God to pardon him, saying she does so wholeheartedly, yet no man grieves her heart like he does—a double meaning referring to her love pain.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She says that’s because the traitorous murderer is still alive.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet ambiguously agrees, saying he is out of her reach, and wishes she alone could avenge Tybalt’s death—meaning she wants no one else to harm Romeo. This is verbal irony hiding her true loyalty.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She promises revenge on Romeo, telling Juliet not to cry anymore. She will send someone to Mantua to poison the banished runaway so he will join Tybalt in death, hoping this will satisfy Juliet.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says she will never be satisfied with Romeo until she sees him dead—but she means her heart is pained for her cousin. She pretends to want to poison Romeo herself, but secretly she is expressing her anguish that she cannot be with him to express her love, which now feels like a debt to Tybalt.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She tells Juliet to find the poison and she will find a man to deliver it, then abruptly changes the subject to joyful news.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says joy is welcome in such a needy time and politely asks what the news is.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She says Juliet has a caring father who has arranged a sudden, unexpected day of joy to cheer her up.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks what day that is.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She announces that next Thursday morning, County Paris will marry Juliet at Saint Peter’s Church.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet swears he will not make her a joyful bride. She is shocked by the rush to marry before Paris has even courted her. She refuses to marry now, and if she does, she says it will be Romeo—whom she pretends to hate—rather than Paris.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She tells Juliet to tell her father this herself and see how he takes it.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He enters and uses a metaphor comparing Juliet’s tears to a storm at sea: her eyes are the sea, her body a ship, her sighs the wind, and the storm will capsize her if it doesn’t stop. He then asks his wife if she has delivered their decision.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She says Juliet refuses the match and thanks them, adding angrily that she wishes the fool were married to her grave.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He is outraged, asking if she isn’t grateful and proud that they have arranged such a worthy bridegroom for someone as unworthy as her.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says she is not proud of what she hates, but she is thankful for their intentions, which were meant lovingly.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He mocks her contradictory reasoning and angrily orders her to prepare for marriage to Paris on Thursday or he will drag her there. He insults her as a sickly corpse, a burden, and pale-faced.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She exclaims in shock, asking if he is mad.

speaker: JULIET
content: On her knees, she begs her father to listen patiently to just one word.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He calls Juliet a worthless burden and commands her to marry Paris on Thursday or be disowned. He forbids any reply, saying his hand itches to strike her. He laments that their only child has become a curse.

speaker: NURSE
content: She blesses Juliet and blames Capulet for scolding her so harshly.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He sarcastically calls the Nurse 'wisdom' and tells her to be quiet and gossip with her friends instead.

speaker: NURSE
content: She insists she has said nothing treasonous.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He exclaims 'God ye good-en' (a mild oath) in frustration.

speaker: NURSE
content: She asks if she is not allowed to speak.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He calls her a mumbling fool and tells her to save her solemn advice for gossip sessions, not for here.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She tells Capulet he is too angry.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Swearing, he says he is driven mad. He explains he has constantly worked to arrange a good marriage for Juliet with Paris, a well-born, handsome, virtuous man. He rages that she, a whining puppet, refuses. He gives her a choice: marry Paris or be disowned and left to beg or die in the streets, vowing never to help her again.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks if heaven has no pity for her grief. She begs her mother to delay the marriage or let her die and be buried with Tybalt.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She refuses to speak to Juliet and says she can do as she likes, for she is done with her.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks the Nurse how to prevent this marriage, since Romeo, her husband, is alive and her vows are in heaven. She wonders how her vows can return unless Romeo dies. She feels heaven is scheming against her and begs the Nurse for comfort.

speaker: NURSE
content: She advises Juliet to marry Paris, since Romeo is banished and unlikely to return. She praises Paris as far superior to Romeo, calling Romeo a dishcloth compared to an eagle. She says Juliet should be happy with this match because her first marriage is effectively over.

speaker: JULIET
content: She asks if the Nurse is speaking sincerely from her heart.

speaker: NURSE
content: She swears she is speaking from her heart and soul, or else may both be cursed.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says 'Amen', ironically accepting the Nurse’s curse and signaling her betrayal.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse simply says 'What?' in response to Juliet's previous line, showing her surprise or confusion.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet sarcastically says the Nurse has comforted her very much, then tells her to inform Lady Capulet that she has gone to Friar Lawrence's cell to confess and be absolved after displeasing her father. This shows Juliet's bitter irony and her plan to seek the Friar's help.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says 'Indeed, I will' and calls this a wise course of action before exiting. 'Marry' here is an archaic interjection meaning 'indeed' or 'by Mary'.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet angrily calls the Nurse an 'ancient damnation' and wicked fiend, questioning whether it's worse for the Nurse to want her to break her marriage vow or to criticize Romeo with the same tongue that praised him so often. She dismisses the Nurse as her confidante and resolves to see the Friar for a solution, adding that if all else fails she can kill herself. This speech marks Juliet's complete break from the Nurse and shows her desperation.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He expresses surprise that the wedding is set for Thursday, noting the short time frame.

speaker: PARIS
content: He explains that Capulet wants it this way, and he is not reluctant to slow down his haste.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He points out that Paris does not know Juliet's feelings and calls the situation irregular and troubling.

speaker: PARIS
content: He says Juliet weeps excessively for Tybalt, so he has avoided speaking of love, since love (Venus) does not belong in a grieving house. Capulet thinks her deep sorrow is dangerous and arranges the marriage to stop her tears by giving her company.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: In an aside, he wishes he did not know why the marriage should be delayed, then announces Juliet's arrival.

speaker: PARIS
content: He greets Juliet warmly as his wife-to-be.

speaker: JULIET
content: She replies cautiously that she may be his wife only if she becomes one.

speaker: PARIS
content: He insists that it will and must happen this Thursday.

speaker: JULIET
content: She resignedly accepts that what must happen will happen.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He dryly comments that her statement is an undeniable truth.

speaker: PARIS
content: He asks if she has come to confess to the Friar.

speaker: JULIET
content: She evasively replies that answering would mean confessing to Paris.

speaker: PARIS
content: He urges her not to deny to the Friar that she loves him.

speaker: JULIET
content: She ambiguously says she will confess she loves the Friar, playing on words.

speaker: PARIS
content: He insists she will say she loves him.

speaker: JULIET
content: She says if she says she loves him, it would be more valuable said behind his back than to his face, implying insincerity or reluctance.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris remarks that Juliet's face is disfigured by her tears, suggesting her grief is visible and excessive.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet replies that her tears have not worsened her appearance, since it was already bad enough before they fell, implying her sorrow is justified.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris claims her words insult her face more than her tears do, accusing her of self-slander.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet defends herself by saying truth cannot be slander, and she spoke only about her own face.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris asserts that her face belongs to him (as her betrothed), so she has slandered it by speaking ill of it.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet ambiguously agrees, saying her face may not be her own, then abruptly asks Friar Lawrence if he is free to speak now or later at mass.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar says he is available for his sorrowful daughter and asks Paris to leave them alone.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris agrees not to interrupt, reminds Juliet he will wake her early on Thursday for their wedding, and bids farewell with a kiss.

speaker: JULIET
content: Once Paris leaves, Juliet urgently asks the Friar to shut the door and join her in weeping, feeling hopeless and beyond help.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar says he already knows her distress about the forced marriage to Paris, which overwhelms his ability to think of a solution.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet demands a way to prevent the marriage, threatening suicide with a knife if the Friar cannot help. She vows death before betraying Romeo, and insists the Friar advise her immediately or she will kill herself.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar stops her and proposes a desperate plan: if she is willing to die, she might risk a death-like state to avoid shame and escape the wedding.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet eagerly agrees to any terrifying alternative—jumping from a tower, walking among thieves, hiding with serpents or bears, or lying among corpses—to remain faithful to Romeo without fear.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He instructs her to consent to the wedding, then drink a potion that will make her appear dead for 42 hours. She will be laid in the Capulet tomb, where Romeo will rescue her upon waking. He warns her not to let fear weaken her resolve.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet eagerly demands the potion, dismissing any talk of fear.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He urges her to be strong in her decision and promises to send a friar quickly to Mantua with letters for Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
content: She prays for love to give her courage, and that courage will provide the means to endure. She bids a final goodbye to her father, knowing she may not see him again.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet orders his servant to invite all the guests on the list and then tells another servant to hire twenty skilled cooks.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: The servant assures Capulet that he will test the cooks by seeing if they can lick their fingers, implying he will hire only competent ones.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet questions how licking fingers can serve as a test of the cooks' skill.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: The servant explains that a bad cook cannot lick his own fingers, so he will not hire anyone who fails this test.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet dismisses the servant to carry out the task.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse confirms that Juliet has gone to Friar Laurence.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet hopes the Friar might help Juliet, then calls her a stubborn, willful girl just as she enters.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse points out Juliet returning from confession with a cheerful expression.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet addresses Juliet as headstrong and asks where she has been wandering.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says she has learned to repent disobeying her father and has been directed by Friar Laurence to beg his pardon, promising future obedience.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Overjoyed, Capulet orders someone to fetch Count Paris and announces the wedding will take place tomorrow morning.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet claims she met Paris at the Friar's cell and showed him appropriate affection without overstepping modesty.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet expresses his happiness, insists on seeing Paris immediately, and praises Friar Laurence for helping the whole city.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks the Nurse to come to her room and help choose suitable clothes and accessories for the wedding tomorrow.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet objects, saying there is enough time before Thursday, the original wedding date.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet overrules his wife, telling the Nurse to go with Juliet and confirming the wedding is moved to tomorrow.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She worries they are running short on supplies for the wedding feast and notes that night is approaching.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He dismisses her concern, promising to take charge and ensure everything is ready. He tells his wife to help Juliet prepare, while he stays up to manage the household and visit Paris to finalize wedding plans. He feels relieved because Juliet has stopped resisting the marriage.

speaker: JULIET
content: She agrees the wedding clothes are fine but asks the Nurse to leave her alone tonight, explaining she needs to say prayers to ask heaven to bless her troubled, sinful situation. This shows her using piety as a pretext to be alone for the potion plan.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She interrupts to ask if Juliet is busy and if she needs help, showing her mother’s brisk, practical manner but little warmth.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet says they have already gathered what is needed for tomorrow and asks to be left alone, suggesting the Nurse stay with her mother since she must be busy with the sudden wedding preparations. This reinforces her isolation strategy.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She bids Juliet good night and tells her to go to bed and rest because she needs it, then exits with the Nurse.

speaker: JULIET
content: Alone, she expresses dread that they may not meet again. A chilling fear runs through her, nearly stopping her life’s warmth. She considers calling the Nurse back but decides she must face this grim situation alone. Taking the vial, she worries: if the potion fails, she’ll have to marry Paris—but her dagger will prevent that. She fears the Friar may have given her poison to avoid dishonor from her previous marriage to Romeo, but she trusts his holy reputation. She then imagines waking too early in the tomb, suffocating in the airless vault, or going mad from the horror—the stench, shrieks like mandrakes (whose roots were said to drive hearers insane), and the presence of Tybalt’s rotting corpse and ancestors’ bones. In frenzy, she might play with their bones or use one to smash her own skull. She hallucinates Tybalt’s ghost seeking Romeo, then toasts Romeo and drinks the potion. This soliloquy reveals her terror and resolve, heightening suspense before she takes the drug.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet tells the Nurse to take keys and get more spices for the wedding preparations.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says the kitchen staff are asking for dates and quinces, which are fruits used in pastries.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet urges everyone to hurry, noting it is 3 a.m. and telling the Nurse to check the baked meats and not worry about expense.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tells Capulet to go to bed, calling him a cot-quean (a man who does housework) and warning he will be sick from staying up all night.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet dismisses her concern, saying he has stayed up all night for lesser reasons and never gotten sick.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet teases that he used to chase women (a mouse-hunt) but she will prevent him from such late nights now.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet mutters jealous-hood, meaning jealousy, as the servants enter with kitchen supplies.

speaker: FIRST SERVANT
content: The servant says he has things for the cook but does not know exactly what they are.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet tells him to hurry and fetch drier logs, and to ask Peter for their location.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: The servant jokes that he has a head (intelligence) to find logs without bothering Peter.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet praises the servant as a merry whoreson (jovial fellow) and says he will be a loggerhead (blockhead). He notes it is day and Paris will arrive with music, then calls the Nurse to wake and dress Juliet while he greets Paris.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tries to wake Juliet, calling her various affectionate names and scolding her for sleeping in. She jokes that Juliet should sleep now because Paris will keep her awake on their wedding night. She then grows concerned at Juliet's lack of response, decides she must wake her, and finally realizes Juliet appears dead, crying out in distress and calling for aqua vitae (a strong liquor) and the Capulets.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet enters and asks what the commotion is about.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse exclaims that it is a sorrowful day.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She asks what has happened.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tells her to look and calls it a grievous day.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Seeing Juliet, she cries out in anguish, calling Juliet her only life and begging her to revive or else she will die too, then calls for help.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet enters, impatiently telling them to bring Juliet out because Paris has arrived.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tells him Juliet is dead, alas.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet echoes the Nurse, lamenting repeatedly that Juliet is dead.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He examines Juliet and finds her cold, with still blood and stiff joints, confirming she has been dead for some time. He compares Death to a frost that has killed the sweetest flower in the field.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse again cries what a lamentable day it is.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet calls it a woeful time.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He says Death has taken Juliet to make him grieve, and now it has stolen his ability to speak.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar arrives with Paris and asks if the bride is ready to go to church.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He answers bitterly that she is ready to go but not to return. He tells Paris that Death has slept with his bride, deflowering her, and that Death is now his son-in-law and heir to all he owns.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris says he has long looked forward to this wedding morning, and now it shows him this terrible sight instead.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She curses this day as wretched and hateful, calling it the most miserable hour ever witnessed in time's long journey. She had only one beloved child to bring her joy and comfort, but cruel death has taken that child away.

speaker: NURSE
content: She exclaims repeatedly about the woeful and lamentable day, declaring it the darkest day she has ever seen. Her repetition emphasizes overwhelming grief.

speaker: PARIS
content: He feels deceived, wronged, and slain by death, calling death detestable and cruel. He laments not life itself, but love that persists even in death.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He describes Juliet as despised, distressed, and killed, asking why this uncomfortable (distressing) time had to ruin their celebration. He declares his child dead and with her, all his joys are buried.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He tells them to be quiet and ashamed, saying that disorder cannot be cured by more disorder. He argues that heaven now has Juliet entirely, which is better for her since she lives eternally. He chides them for weeping when she is exalted in heaven, saying they love her poorly by mourning when she is well off. He states that a long marriage is not the best; dying young after marriage is better. He tells them to dry tears, place rosemary (a funeral herb) on her body, dress her well, and take her to church, explaining that while natural grief makes us cry, reason should bring joy.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He observes that everything planned for celebration has turned to funeral use: instruments become funeral bells, wedding feast becomes burial meal, hymns become sad songs, and bridal flowers adorn a corpse.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He instructs Capulet, Lady Capulet, and Paris to go prepare to follow Juliet’s body to the grave. He warns that the heavens frown on them for some wrong, and they should not oppose heaven’s will further.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He remarks that they can pack up their instruments and leave.

speaker: NURSE
content: She tells the musicians to put away their instruments, acknowledging this is a pitiful situation.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He replies, 'by my troth' (truly), the situation could be improved — a pun on 'case' as both situation and instrument case.

speaker: PETER
content: He calls for the musicians to play 'Heart’s ease,' a popular tune, saying if they want him to live they should play it.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He asks why 'Heart’s ease'?

speaker: PETER
content: He explains that his heart plays 'My heart is full' (of sorrow), so he wants a merry dump (a slow, sad dance tune) to comfort him.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He refuses, saying it’s not the time to play now.

speaker: PETER
content: He asks if they really won’t play.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He simply says no.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter threatens to beat the musicians soundly, meaning thoroughly or severely.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician misunderstands and asks what Peter will give them, expecting a payment.

speaker: PETER
content: He says he will give them no money but a gleek, meaning a jest or taunt, and calls them minstrels insultingly.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician retorts by calling Peter a serving-creature, a demeaning term for a servant.

speaker: PETER
content: He threatens to hit the musician's head with a dagger and says he will carry no crotchets, meaning both quarter notes in music and whims or complaints. He then puns on musical notes re and fa, meaning he will attack them.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician plays on Peter's words, saying if you re and fa us, you note us, meaning both musical notes and observe/attack us.

speaker: SECOND MUSICIAN
content: He asks Peter to put away his dagger and show his wit instead, using put out to mean display.

speaker: PETER
content: He says he will attack with his wit, dry-beat meaning thrash without drawing blood, and put up his dagger. He then quotes a poem about music soothing grief and questions why it says silver sound, challenging each musician in turn.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He answers that silver has a sweet sound, taking the phrase literally.

speaker: PETER
content: He dismisses this as prates, meaning idle chatter.

speaker: SECOND MUSICIAN
content: He offers a pun that musicians sound for silver, meaning they play for money.

speaker: PETER
content: He rejects this answer too as prates.

speaker: THIRD MUSICIAN
content: He admits he does not know what to say.

speaker: PETER
content: He sarcastically says he will answer for the musician: music has a silver sound because musicians are paid in silver, not gold. He finishes the verse and exits. This mocks the musicians' poverty.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: He calls Peter a pestilent knave, meaning a troublesome rogue.

speaker: SECOND MUSICIAN
content: He suggests they ignore Peter, go inside, wait for the mourners, and stay for dinner.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo begins hopeful, saying his dreams suggest good news is coming, and he feels unusually cheerful. He dreamed Juliet kissed him back to life, making him feel like an emperor. He reflects that even love's mere shadows bring joy, but then Balthasar arrives. He eagerly asks for letters from Friar Laurence and about Juliet's well-being, insisting nothing can be wrong if she is fine.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar says Juliet is well in the sense that her soul is with angels, but her body lies in the Capulet tomb. He explains he saw her placed there and rode quickly to bring the news, apologizing for the bad tidings since Romeo tasked him with this duty.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo immediately accepts this as truth and defiantly challenges fate itself. He orders Balthasar to get ink, paper, and post-horses for his departure tonight, showing his rash decision to return to Verona.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar urges patience, noting Romeo's pale and wild appearance suggests some disaster is imminent.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo dismisses Balthasar's concern as mistaken and repeats his command to leave and fetch the horses, asking again if there is a letter from the Friar.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar simply replies there is no letter.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says it does not matter and sends Balthasar to hire the horses, saying he will follow shortly. Alone, he resolves to join Juliet in death tonight and begins to scheme.

speaker: APOTHECARY
content: The Apothecary responds to Romeo's call, asking who is shouting for him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo beckons the Apothecary, noting his poverty and offering forty ducats for a fast-acting poison that will spread through the veins and kill as quickly as gunpowder fired from a cannon.

speaker: APOTHECARY
content: The Apothecary admits he has such deadly drugs, but says Mantuan law imposes the death penalty for anyone who sells them.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo argues that the Apothecary is already wretched, with hunger in his cheeks and despair in his eyes, and that the world and its laws are no friend to him. He urges him to break the law and accept the money, since the world offers no lawful way to become rich.

speaker: APOTHECARY
content: The Apothecary consents, saying his poverty agrees, but not his will.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo replies that he is paying the Apothecary's poverty, not his will.

speaker: APOTHECARY
content: The Apothecary instructs him to dissolve the poison in any liquid and drink it; even with the strength of twenty men, it would kill him immediately.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo hands over the gold, calling it a worse poison to men's souls, causing more harm in the world than the Apothecary's banned drugs. He says he sells poison (the gold), while the Apothecary sold none. He tells him to buy food and gain weight, then calls the poison a cordial (a restorative) rather than a poison, as he will use it at Juliet's grave.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: Friar John calls out for Friar Lawrence, addressing him as a fellow Franciscan friar.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence recognizes Friar John's voice and asks for news from Romeo in Mantua, or for a letter if Romeo wrote down his thoughts.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: He explains that while searching for another friar to accompany him, the town health inspectors quarantined them in a house suspected of plague, preventing his journey to Mantua.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He urgently asks who then delivered his letter to Romeo.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: He replies that he could not send the letter or find a messenger because everyone was too afraid of catching the plague.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He exclaims at the unlucky event, noting the letter was not trivial but urgent and important; neglecting it may cause great harm. He orders Friar John to fetch an iron crowbar immediately.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: He agrees to go and bring the crowbar.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He resolves to go alone to the tomb where Juliet will wake in three hours; she will be angry Romeo wasn't informed, so he'll write again and shelter her until Romeo arrives—a living body enclosed in a dead man's tomb.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris tells his page to take the torch and stand at a distance, then to extinguish it so they are not seen. He instructs the boy to lie flat under a yew tree with his ear to the ground to detect anyone approaching by the sound of loose soil, and to whistle as a signal. He then takes the flowers and orders the page to go.

speaker: PAGE
content: The page admits he is almost too scared to stay alone in the churchyard but resolves to take the risk.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris addresses Juliet as a sweet flower and says he will adorn her bridal bed with flowers, though her canopy is only dust and stones. He vows to water her grave nightly with sweet water or, lacking that, with his own tears. He promises to perform these funeral rites for her every night by strewing her grave and weeping.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks Balthasar for the tools and gives him a letter to deliver to his father in the morning. He takes the light and orders Balthasar to stay away and not interfere, no matter what he hears or sees. He explains he is entering the tomb partly to see Juliet's face but mainly to retrieve a ring from her finger for an important purpose. He threatens to tear Balthasar apart if he returns out of suspicion, saying his intentions are wilder than tigers or the sea.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar agrees to leave and not bother Romeo.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says this shows friendship, gives him money, and wishes him a prosperous life before saying farewell.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Despite his promise, Balthasar decides to hide nearby because he fears Romeo's looks and doubts his intentions.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo addresses the tomb as a detestable stomach or womb of death, stuffed with the earth's dearest treasure (Juliet). He forces its rotten jaws open and says, in defiance, he will cram it with more food.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris recognizes Romeo as the banished Montague who killed his love's cousin (Tybalt), which he believes caused Juliet's death. He assumes Romeo has come to desecrate the bodies and decides to arrest him. He orders Romeo to stop his unhallowed work, asks if vengeance can go beyond death, calls him a condemned villain, and tells him he must obey and go to his death.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo admits he must die and that is why he came. He urges the youth not to provoke a desperate man, to leave and think of the dead, who should frighten him. He begs him not to make him sin again by driving him to fury, saying he loves him more than himself because he came armed against himself. He tells him to go, live, and later say a madman showed mercy by telling him to run.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris rejects Romeo's plea and arrests him as a criminal.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks if Paris is provoking him and then attacks.

speaker: PAGE
content: The page sees them fighting and says he will go call the watch.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris, dying, asks Romeo, if he is merciful, to open the tomb and lay him with Juliet.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo agrees to bury Paris, recognizing him as Mercutio's kinsman and recalling he was to marry Juliet. He calls him a fellow sufferer in misfortune and says he will place him in a triumphant grave—or rather a lantern, because Juliet's beauty lights the vault. He reflects that dying men are often cheerful, a 'lightning before death,' but wonders if this applies to him. He marvels that death has not dimmed Juliet's beauty, seeing color still in her lips and cheeks. He addresses Tybalt, asks forgiveness, and wonders if death is amorous and keeps Juliet as his lover. Resolving to stay, he declares he will set up his eternal rest here, free himself from fate, and embrace death. He drinks the poison, toasts Juliet, and dies.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence calls on Saint Francis for help and notes how often his old feet have stumbled at graves tonight. He asks who is there keeping company with the dead so late.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar identifies himself as a friend who knows Friar Lawrence well.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He blesses Balthasar and asks about a torch he sees burning uselessly for grubs and skulls in the Capulet tomb.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He confirms the torch is at the Capulet monument and that his master, whom the Friar loves, is there.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He asks who the master is.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He answers that it is Romeo.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He asks how long Romeo has been there.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He says Romeo has been there for half an hour.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He tells Balthasar to come with him to the vault.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He refuses, saying Romeo thinks he has left and threatened to kill him if he stayed to spy on his plans.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He decides to go alone, expressing fear that something terrible has happened.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: He recounts a dream in which his master fought and killed another man.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He discovers blood at the tomb entrance and discarded swords, then finds Romeo and Paris dead inside. He notes Juliet is waking.

speaker: JULIET
content: She greets the Friar and asks for Romeo, remembering she should be in the tomb.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He urges her to leave quickly because the watch is coming, reveals Romeo and Paris are dead, and offers to place her in a convent.

speaker: JULIET
content: She refuses to leave and tells the Friar to go.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He calls from offstage for someone to lead the way.

speaker: JULIET
content: She hears a noise and resolves to act quickly. She calls the dagger 'happy' because it will end her life, then stabs herself, saying her body will be its sheath and she can now die beside Romeo. This is her suicide speech, completing the tragedy.

speaker: PAGE
content: The Page points out the location of the tomb by the burning torch, guiding the Watch to the scene.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He notes the bloody ground and orders a search, telling his men to arrest anyone they find. He then describes the pitiful scene: Paris slain, Juliet newly dead though buried two days earlier. He sends others to inform the Prince and the families.

speaker: SECOND WATCH
content: He announces that they have found Romeo's servant Balthasar in the churchyard.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He says they see the physical evidence of the tragedy but cannot understand the true cause without more information. This uses wordplay on 'ground' meaning both earth and reason.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He orders Balthasar held securely until the Prince arrives.

speaker: PRINCE
content: He asks what misfortune has arisen so early that disturbs his morning rest, expressing annoyance at being summoned.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He wonders what the cause is of the loud cries he hears outside.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She reports that people in the street are shouting the names Romeo, Juliet, and Paris, and running with loud cries toward the family tomb.

speaker: PRINCE
content: He asks what frightening news is startling his ears.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He reports to the Prince that Paris is slain, Romeo is dead, and Juliet—previously buried—is newly killed and still warm.

speaker: PRINCE
content: He commands them to investigate and discover how this foul murder happened.

speaker: FIRST WATCH
content: He informs the Prince that they have detained Friar Lawrence and Romeo's servant, who had tools suitable for opening tombs.

speaker: CAPULET
content: He exclaims in horror at seeing Juliet bleed, then observes that Romeo's dagger has missed its mark—its owner is dead—and has been wrongly sheathed in his daughter's breast. 'Mista'en' means mistaken; 'his house' refers to Romeo's body.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She says the sight of death is like a funeral bell tolling for her own old age, warning that she will soon follow to the grave.

speaker: PRINCE
content: He addresses Montague, noting that he has risen early only to see his son and heir dead even earlier.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague reports that his wife has died tonight from grief over their son's exile, and he fears more sorrows await his old age.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince tells Montague to look and he will see the cause of further grief.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague scolds Romeo for his lack of manners in rushing ahead of his father to a grave.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince calls for a temporary halt to emotional outbursts until the facts are known, promising to guide them through their grief and demanding the suspects be brought forward.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar admits he is the most suspected but least able to prevent the murder, given the circumstances, and he stands ready to both accuse and clear himself.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince orders the Friar to immediately tell what he knows.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar explains he married Romeo and Juliet, gave Juliet a sleeping potion to avoid marrying Paris, but his letter to Romeo failed, leading to both lovers' deaths and Juliet's suicide. He admits the Nurse knew of the marriage and offers his life if he is at fault.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince acknowledges the Friar's holy reputation and asks for Romeo's servant to testify.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar says he told Romeo of Juliet's death, after which Romeo hurried from Mantua to the tomb, gave him a letter for his father, and threatened him with death if he stayed.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince asks for the letter and inquires about Paris's page, asking what his master was doing there.

speaker: PAGE
content: The page says Paris came to strew flowers on Juliet's grave, told him to keep away, then drew his sword when another arrived with a light, prompting the page to fetch the watch.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince confirms the Friar's story with Romeo's letter, which says he bought poison to die with Juliet, and he rebukes the families for causing these deaths through their feud, noting his own loss of kinsmen.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet offers Montague his hand in reconciliation, saying this handshake is his daughter's jointure (marriage settlement), as he can ask for nothing more.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague promises to honor Juliet with a golden statue in Verona, so valued that no other will compare.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet vows to match this with an equally rich statue of Romeo beside Juliet, calling them poor sacrifices of their families' feud.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince concludes that a sad peace arrives this morning, the sun hides in sorrow, and they must discuss these events further, with some pardoned and some punished, for no story holds more woe than this.
